name: Offensive Security
description: learn how to secure yourself or your company from the upcoming threat.

tutorials.title: Mimikatz
tutorials.description: A tool used for extracting plaintext passwords, hashes, PINs, and Kerberos tickets from memory, often used after gaining elevated privileges.

tutorials.title: Meterpreter
tutorials.description: A post-exploitation tool from the Metasploit framework that allows remote control over a compromised system, including running commands, uploading/downloading files, and lateral movement.

tutorials.title: Empire
tutorials.description: A post-exploitation framework that provides PowerShell and Python agents for maintaining access to compromised systems, executing commands, and lateral movement.

tutorials.title: BloodHound
tutorials.description: A tool for mapping out Active Directory environments to identify attack paths for further privilege escalation or lateral movement.

tutorials.title: PowerSploit
tutorials.description: A collection of PowerShell scripts used for post-exploitation tasks such as privilege escalation, credential harvesting, and maintaining persistence.

tutorials.title: PsExec
tutorials.description: A tool from Sysinternals for executing commands on remote systems, often used for lateral movement within a network.

tutorials.title: SharpHound
tutorials.description: A tool for collecting data from Active Directory environments to be analyzed by BloodHound for identifying privilege escalation paths.

tutorials.title: Golden Ticket Attack with Mimikatz
tutorials.description: An advanced technique using Mimikatz to create Kerberos tickets, allowing for domain control and persistence.

tutorials.title: Cobalt Strike
tutorials.description: A commercial adversary simulation tool used for post-exploitation, command-and-control, and lateral movement during red team exercises.

tutorials.title: CrackMapExec
tutorials.description: A tool for automating post-exploitation tasks like credential validation, enumeration, and executing commands across a network.
